Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Disease at the margins of species ranges: anther-smut on alpine species
Award.AbstractNarration:
Infectious diseases can be devastating to humans and agriculture, but much less is known about how disease affects natural populations. This study will investigate the impact of a fungal disease, anther-smut, on the distribution of alpine plants, and will serve as a model for assessing how sterilizing diseases affect natural populations. The study will be carried out in an area where there is heavy disease infestation on many species, and steep environmental gradients in multiple valleys, enabling systematic studies of the factors that influence disease processes at the margins of species distributions. Genetic and ecological experiments, theoretical models, and long-term monitoring will investigate how disease affects the limits of species' ranges and how marginal populations may be foci for disease emergence through transmission of infections between host species.

This research will enhance international collaborations, support local conservation efforts, and provide a field course, training and hands-on research experience in infectious disease biology for researchers and undergraduate students. Alpine regions are themselves fragile environments severely threatened by climate change and this study will establish baseline information essential for managing these plant communities in relation to disease and the rapid environmental changes that are occurring in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the importance of pathogens in limiting the range distribution of their hosts, using anther-smut disease as a model system. In this system, disease can often affect up to half of the individuals in a population. Our results showed that this vector-transmitted disease which causes complete sterility is present on numerous species, and that in many of these it often occurs right up to the range margins of its hosts, and at high frequency. There is therefore no evidence for a “disease free halo” around the edges of the host range as is often assumed. This disease causes large reductions in population size, indicating that it is likely affecting the distribution of its host species. Our research established the baseline distribution of disease in 23 alpine species that will be invaluable in examining long term effects of climate change in relation to disease incidence and species distributions. Our detailed demographic studies also showed that mixed transmission modes were important in maintaining disease in this system, something that had been postulated in theory but that had not been demonstrated. We also developed new approaches to studying vector-transmitted diseases that are likely to be applicable to human populations and other domesticated and wild species. We also developed new theory about the relationship between host lifespan and evolution of disease resistance. This research furthered international collaboration with Italian scientists, and involved many undergraduates who have gone on to successful careers in biological research, public health, or medicine.
